coverageText:
Oh, wondrous Nature, thou art fair and bright,  
In thee doth bloom a grace beyond compare.  
Thy verdant garments flourish in daylight,  
And gentle winds thy fragrant incense bear.  

The sky, a sapphire dome, doth span o'erhead,  
Adorned with clouds in scrolls of azure hue.  
The sun, a fiery orb, o'er all doth shed  
Its golden rays, igniting dawn anew.  

Fair blossoms rise beneath each tender leaf,  
Their colors vivid as Apollo's crown.  
The babbling brooks, in tune with time's brief grief,  
Sing gentle hymns to calm the world's renown.  

Thou cradle life and secrets yet untold,  
In shadowed valleys and on lofty peaks.  
Thy mystic ways in beauty will unfold,  
Of thee, the soul of every poet speaks.  

Oh, Nature, queen of heaven and of earth,  
Within thy bosom all thy wonders lie.  
And we, mere mortals, honor thy great worth,  
For in thy grace our hearts eternally shall fly.
